question.name: 2.3.2.1 Inverse of a function
question.questiontext:
Inverse of a function

We have seen that a function can be regarded as taking an input, \(x\), and processing it in some way to produce a single output \(f(x)\) as shown in part (a) of the figure below.

A natural question to ask is whether we can find another function that will reverse the process. In other words, can we find a function that will start with \(f(x)\) and process it to produce \(x\) again? This idea is also shown in part (b) of the figure. If we can find such a function it is called the inverse function to \(f(x)\) and is given the symbol \(f^{-1}(x)\).


Do not confuse the ‘\(-1\)’ with an index, or power. Here the superscript is used purely as the notation for the inverse function. Note that the composite function \(f^{-1}(f(x))=x\) as shown in figure below.

Example

Find the inverse function to \(f(x)=3x-8\).

Solution

The given function takes an input, \(x\) and produces an output \(3x-8\). The inverse function, \(f^{-1}\), must take an input \(3x-8\) and give an output \(x\). That is

\(\qquad f^{-1}(3x-8) = x \, .\)

If we introduce a new variable \(z=3x-8\), and transpose this for \(x\) to give

\(\qquad x=\dfrac{z+8}{3} \qquad \text{then}\qquad f^{-1}(z)=\dfrac{z+8}{3} \, .\)

So the rule for \(f^{-1}\) is add 8 to the input and divide the result by 3. Writing \(f^{-1}\) with \(x\) as its argument gives

\(\qquad f^{-1}(x)= \dfrac{x+8}{3} \, .\)

This is the inverse function.

Not all functions possess an inverse function. In fact, only one-to-one functions do so. If a function is many-to-one the process to reverse it would require many outputs from one input contradicting the definition of a function.


Try for yourself: Explain why a many-to-one function does not have an inverse function. Give an example.
